discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Immediately Onboard BUSD & Introduce 0% PSM

content.content: Note: This is an urgent request to expedite a MIP6 & PSM launch for BUSD to diversify DAI’s collateral backing. DAI is backed nearly entirely by a single centralized collateral in a defaulting environment.    TLDR   >80% of DAI is backed by USDC.  USDC may or may not be compromised.  Surprisingly, large players have been mismanaging customer funds, going under, and defaulting. It is feasible that Circle may have mismanaged USDC.   >80% of DAI is backed by USDC.  A potential default could be imminent. This would be an existential risk to DAI.      Immediately onboard BUSD as collateral.   BUSD will be a temporary alternative to phase out USDC or at least diversify the risk of single collateral defaulting.    Immediately introduce a PSM for BUSD identical to USDC’s w/ 0% swap fee. Gradually (quickly) deploy all stablecoin backing of DAI.    Why BUSD? What is the urgency? In a defaulting environment, imagine what a shocker it would be… if it’s discovered that USDC (not Tether, not BUSD)… but Circle, was the one gambling with their customer’s funds? If Circle is underwater for whatever reason, our entire collateral base could be defaulted on.  We’re ~80% exposed to USDC right now.  BUSD is fairly liquid on-chain. Binance has as good a reputation as anyone else and has been in the space for a long time. Adding BUSD and launching an identical PSM would diversify our backing temporarily. Gradually, we would move off from these kinds of collaterals, but right now, we are too exposed to USDC.  Add 0% PSM for BUSD  Clone the Peg Stability Module with a 0% swap fee for BUSD.  BUSD is slightly less liquid on-chain than USDC but liquid enough to meet our needs.   BUSD will be a good stop-gap while we offload all dependency on centralized stablecoins.   BUSD Liquidity (As of 06/29/20}   Cidculating Supply: $17,381,453,038  MarketCap: $17,563,877,488  BUSD Fully Diluted Market Cap: $17,385,769,458  Vvolume [24h]: $5,748,927,330  Circulating Supply: 17.37B BUSD  Website: Paxos BUSD   Contract: 0x4Fabb145d64652a948d72533023f6E7A623C7C53    Signal Request Details I am proposing three SRs:  One to onboard BUSD. One to introduce a PSM for BUSD. One to set BUSD PSM tout to 0.      Onboard BUSD as Collateral?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        Introduce PSM for BUSD?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        Set BUSD PSM tout to 0?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters     This poll will run until July 9th. 2022-06-30T00:00:00Z→2022-07-09T11:00:00Z If successful, an on-chain vote will be held to confirm the changes.  Also, someone will have to do the MIP6 and PSM.   Next Steps  Move away from pure USDC backing.
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post is proposing to onboard BUSD as collateral and introduce a PSM for BUSD to diversify DAI's collateral backing. The post explains the reasons for the proposal and provides details about BUSD's liquidity and market cap. The author also includes a signal request with three SRs and a poll to gather feedback from the community. The post includes a call to action to move away from pure USDC backing.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal
None

content.content: USDC is backing collateral for 52.1% of generated DAI.  The remaining collateral is split among other PSMs, mainly USDP, crypto backed loans and LPs.

content.content: While I think eventually onboarding BUSD as collateral makes sense since it was greenlit before, this post and poll seem rushed as well as need to be guided by facts. For example, beside Twitter posts, don’t think there are clear evidence that Circle is underwater. Also, BUSD is based on PAX and we already saw even if different stablecoin collateral, USDC is widely used as it is easy for fiat onramp as well as liquidity so not sure how much it will help.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: 52.1%  usdc 10.1%  dai-usdc  → 9% ? (idk how to math this one) 6.8% dai-usdc  → 5% ? (same story) 3.3 dai-usdc  → 2.5% ? (same story)  Ok, I get just under 70% give or take… off by a little, still unacceptably high, no?
Doo_StableLab:  For example, beside Twitter posts, don’t think there are clear evidence that Circle is underwater.   …they would lie on the internet?

content.content: Doo_StableLab:  this post and poll seem rushed as well as need to be guided by facts.   @Doo_StableLab, honestly, you’re right. I’m shoving it in like, outta nowhere. I do hope it was for no reason though because that would be bad. … very bad. lol But as it stands, rushed or not, we ae actually vulnerable to a third party right now.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: Existing BUSD MIP6 from July 2020.

If you are trying to onboard a new collateral type, it’s recommended that you start with an application template located here, mips/MIP6c2-Collateral-Application-Template.md at master · makerdao/mips · GitHub There are also the MIP6 Recommended Guideline Metrics for Onchain Collateral Onboarding that are important to do a self assessment on so the community can understand the opportunity and value to the protocol before we go to a greenlight, onchain poll. SRs do not provide the necessary information to onboard new collateral and almost always take longer to onboard vs. starting with a collateral application. I shared a detailed explanation of this specific issue on the Decentralized Voter Committee today (it was recorded). Feel free to use this signaling information to help you with your application. As a reference, the CSI will be updated to track this collateral once your MIP6 is posted to the forum, Collateral Status Index - Google Sheets

content.content: Personally, I love the administration of CZ and I see Binance as an example of how a centralized cryptocurrency company should be done, outside of the technical context BUSD is a good option, there is greater exposure to the public, I do not like that the regulations that Binance did not approve leave it in a bad position to be able to start in a market as large as the United States, but there are multiple agreements with Dubai and Paris that make Binance a company that will stay for the rest of our time, it would be quite good lower the exposure to USDC a little for the simple fact of diversifying the collaterals even more (more than they are)

content.content: A classic example of a post that could age really bad (and I hope not).     Doo_StableLab:  this post and poll seem rushed as well as need to be guided by facts. For example, beside Twitter posts, don’t think there are clear evidence that Circle is underwater.   “Over 50% of our exposure is in USDC” is not fact enough? You don’t need a clear evidence that one of your debtors is underwater to start managing your risk.     Doo_StableLab:  Also, BUSD is based on PAX and we already saw even if different stablecoin collateral, USDC is widely used as it is easy for fiat onramp as well as liquidity so not sure how much it will help.   I’m not going to argue with someone from the @Growth-Core-Unit about the crypto-ramps landscape, because I don’t stand a chance. But from the outside, it seems that Binance (like it or not) is one of the biggest ramps in the world. I would even adventure that they cover regions where Circle is less present. In any case, I applaud @aburban90’s initiative and hope that the Protocol reduces the exposure to any given asset (through this mechanism or others with more revenue for Maker).

Unfortunately the 1st sentence is not a good one - CZ is not the mastermind you think they are (this is based on having worked early days with him). -on topic- I am all for onboarding a paxos-managed stablecoin to makerdao, but we should definitely be aware of Binance-tangential risk.

content.content: juan:  “Over 50% of our exposure is in USDC” is not fact enough?   Sure, over exposure to USDC is a fact, but not the part about it being underwater. In theory, BUSD might be underwater using his logic.     juan:  But from the outside, it seems that Binance (like it or not) is one of the biggest ramps in the world. I would even adventure that they cover regions where Circle is less present.   This part is true. My point was more of even if we onboard it right now, it would still make USDC large majority in foreseeable future. But after more thought, I can see how shifting by let’s say 10% is still an improvement from diversification of risk.

content.content: Once again, I chose the wrong format!  An informal poll probably would have been better, but I do feel like this is actually a very pressing issue, It’s not something we can “circle back to” later.   The old format MIP6 was confusing enough, the new one even more. I wasn’t going to draft it up correctly in time.

content.content: @GovAlpha-Core-Unit Can you comment on this Signal and whether it is proper? There’s a lot going on right now and it’s very disruptive to have something thrown into governance as “immediate”. What does that even mean? I took a quick look and already see confusion. @aburban90 please be considerate of everyone’s time and do some due diligence and collaborate with others a bit on what/how to raise whatever is being attempted here.

content.content: If we do not base it on liquidity after USDT, BUSD is very very liquid and very very heavily traded being the 2nd most traded.  image1652×443 40.9 KB  Also a good alliance with Paxos would allow the entry of DAI to a range of products e.g. Mercado Libre has an alliance with Paxos for crypto payments on its platform. In addition, Paypal, as a crypto buying and selling service, is a custodian of Paxos.

content.content: I would just like to remark that the recent FUD thread on twitter against USDC is not remotely credible.   twitter.com    Geralt Davidson @CryptoInsider23  Circle's USDC scheme is on the brink of collapse. If you read their SPAC IPO filings its clear they have been losing money constantly but theres something dirtier happening underneath. They're at major risk on defaulting on USDC reserves.  A deep dive 🧵 on USDC. 👇 https://t.co/GgN5oeD7gO   6:10 AM - 29 Jun 2022           3.4K                1K            The author suggests Circle is paying their bank partners 5%+ on USD reserves (rather than the obviously correct interpretation that Circle receives money from bank partners). Also confuses Circle Yield product with USDC reserves. Basically it’s just clout chasing. BUSD would be a valuable addition but I don’t think the matter is particularly urgent. I think we should see how we can partner with BUSD and try to build a mutually beneficial relationship, which may take time.

content.content: monet-supply:  BUSD would be a valuable addition   You led the previous MIP6. Would you be down to revive it?     monet-supply:  I don’t think the matter is particularly urgent.   I would argue it is. Maybe we trust Circle fully here, but it is just bad practice to be at the mercy of a single third party ever. It is entirely in Circle’s hands whether we live or die. I’d argue voluntarily forfeiting autonomy for ourselves is not a good decision, even if in hindsight it may have looked okay. Would you or @Sharon9632 be open to picking up where you left off? I’ll drop the SR now if s0.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: aburban90:      monet-supply:  I don’t think the matter is particularly urgent.   I would argue it is. Maybe we trust Circle fully here, but it is just bad practice to be at the mercy of a single third party ever. It is entirely in Circle’s hands whether we live or die.   Ok I agree it is urgent  But imo more on the order of solving in the next couple months rather than weeks or days. I don’t think there’s any evidence that USDC solvency or liquidity is stressed (they have seen huge inflows recently which improve the liquidity situation if anything). There’s also another aspect to this - will diversifying risk actually help Maker survive?  US govt censorship will likely apply to all centralized USD stablecoin issuers so I dont think this offers meaningful protection against regulatory risk If we onboard BUSD, but our USDC holdings remain very high (eg $1 billion or more), we may still have existential level exposure to USDC counterparty/credit risk while also adding existential exposure to BUSD (Paxos credit risk + Binance key management)  Definitely still think we should onboard BUSD and support the signal generally, just not the “immediate” part.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

None of the topics listed match

content.content: I would caution against acting on emotion here. BUSD has merit and has shown stability and liquidity across decentralized and centralized platforms. It also seems to have similar counter-party risk that we are “afraid” of in USDC. Let’s make this happen - but in a level-headed manner that considers all outcomes for the DAO. How are we benefiting from this? How are we exposing ourselves? etc. “Immediately” is a very persuasive word and I acknowledge your passion. It feels we would foster a better outcome by not rushing this signal; a majority of the temp check is abstaining In all these recent conversations it feels pessimistic. Yes, we are over-exposed to USDC - but it could be much worse, with a weaker asset.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: monet-supply:  If we onboard BUSD, but our USDC holdings remain very high (eg $1 billion or more), we may still have existential level exposure to USDC counterparty/credit risk while also adding existential exposure to BUSD (Paxos credit risk + Binance key management)   I think this is a very important point.  Our stablecoin holdings are large enough that adding one counterparty really won’t help matters in any way.  Not that this is a reason to not do it…you have to start somewhere.  But as we currently are, we will be existentially exposed to a few counterparties in the near term.  We have to accept this as a fact and just work to diversify in a levelheaded manner.  But it might be wise to wait for all the market turmoil to clear out before going on this path.  In an environment where there is uncertainty of who might fail next and who might be exposed to failures, being exposed to the strongest assets out there like usdc and treasuries is actually the best position to be in.  You can diversify yourself to 100 counterparties but if we get into a deep global recession, you’re going to start taking losses on the weakest of those counterparties.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Ok, officially shutting this Signal Request.  Votes seem to be overwhelmingly in favor or abstaining.      monet-supply:  Ok I agree it is urgent    @monet-supply implying that it’ll get done… at some point,…     Traster_Tray:  Our stablecoin holdings are large enough that adding one counterparty really won’t help matters in any way.   In the grand scheme, any variant of a USD stable is the same so is a EUR version. I’d still argue it’s better to split that risk up. Mamu, but not all banks fail in extreme meltdowns, none of those are end-game plans.     fig:  “Immediately” is a very persuasive word and I acknowledge your passion.   I hope that in hindsight, it will look like I was just overreacting.   Anyway, now officially shutting this Signal Request.
